Text.Value: Mmm, yes, what a delightful wedge of Old Elturian that was. Doesn't do to parley on an empty stomach, you know. Makes one's words frivolous when they should be grave.
Why, some bread, cheese, and a cup of wine would appear unto me a feast! Surely you won't begrudge me a mite of rest and repast before I get 'out with it'?
And yet - a notion born in lonely hours - come ebb, come flow, come all that is beyond the breadth of our dominion: be a moon unto yourself.
I may be slow to anger, but I will not have you sully this moment of most sorrowful import with ill-considered levity!
The long-awaited question. Now - if you please, Elminster - for the too-long-awaited answer.
Mystra would consider... forgiveness?
Precisely.
If even the gods know, why are we facing these threats alone?
The very purpose of my presence - in a roundabout sort of way.
Right. Ahem. You see...
Gale, m'boy, I've come to address a most pressing matter. I'll speak as plainly as I can, forswearing the accustomed frills that decorate my speech.
The orb.
There's still a long journey ahead. We'll find another way.

It brings me no pleasure saying this, my friend, but such is Mystra's will. Yours must be the sacrifice that will undo the Absolute. And for your sacrifice, you will be redeemed - such is Mystra's promise.
I can't say that so far I've volunteered the entire truth.
Do not discount yourself, and by the same token, do not discount your enemy.
That which I speak of, as Gale well knows, is neither idle nor false. Rather it is... unnatural.
His acts were misguided, yes, but I assure you that deep down he has a heart of - let's say at least silver. Which is more than can be said for the foe you face.
Say what you will, but you can't force Gale to go through with this.
The very same, Gale. And a fair bit miffed he is, too, finding himself forced to expose his best pair of boots to so many miles of country road on your behalf.
You were sent here as an actual divine messenger?
You must find the Heart of the Absolute, whatever that may be, and use yourself as the catalyst that will burn it from this world.
Mystra is aware of the misadventures that have befallen you both. She knows of your strife with the Absolute, that most insidious of evils.
That's monstrous! You're tasking him to kill himself.
Alas, such luxuries require the beneficence of time, and time, as I'm sure our friend here will attest, is the very luxury of which we're all too bereft.

You must know that the Absolute is more dangerous than you can possibly conceive. It threatens all who live - even those who are undying. It threatens the gods, the Weave, the very fabric of the universe itself.
Ah! There you are. I hope you don't mind my having ingratiated myself into the most palatable graces of your provisions. You find me quite sated indeed.
In short, Gale - through his own doing - has become a living explosive that could wipe from this world this very gathering, and much more besides.
But why? Out with it, Elminster. Please!
Even the waves of fate can break upon the shores of will.
To you, I commit into care Gale himself. I count on you to shepherd him well on this strangest of journeys.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: He addresses the player now, rather than Gale.

Text.Value: Oh, for the love of...
I suppose we could part with a few of our rations.
Thank you for that most considerate reminder.
It's all right, Elminster. If ever gallows humour were appropriate, this is its grim-smiling hour.
Surely you could have conjured any feast you liked.
Or some other fortune altogether.
For his folly, Mystra forsook him, but now she has decreed he is to be given a chance of redemption.
Like moons make swell and wane the nescient seas, so too the sky-strewn gods ordain the tidal fates of mortal days.
We'll be rid of both the Absolute and Gale in one fell swoop. Win-win.
Come, come, up you both stand. I, for one, am dying to find out what's for breakfast.
I'm surprised that Mystra demands such a sacrifice. This is hardly her way.
She would consider what she considers to be forgiveness.
Alas. The creature that afflicts you, the ill-begotten magic that it weaves, is inextricably conjoined with both the greater purpose and the greater master that it serves.
Must have been his simulacrum you bested. He always was a cautious traveller.

EditorData.NodeContext: Referring to player previously 'killing' Elminster - it was an illusion. Low and an aside to the player, not meant for anyone else's ears

Text.Value: You know where you went wrong, Gale, and I trust you've told your fellow traveller here the nature of your ills.
She'd do well to place her trust in me in equal measure.
Then you two have much to discuss after I'll have taken my leave.
On my honour, I'm not sure yet I can say the same.
It is done. Both charge and charm have been committed into your care.
I'm not in the habit of taking in vagabonds.
I doubt not your conviction. But Gale has an unnatural advantage.
Elminster?
Oh? And what is he, then, wandering these forlorn barrens over seven hundred miles from home?
Speak fast, then, for none of this pertains to me.
With that, I've said my sorry piece, and need only bestow unto thee the charm I was bid.
Mystra is mistaken. I will be the Absolute's destroyer.
Your friend here denied having the pleasure of your acquaintance, Gale, but I'll assume this feigned ignorance was committed with more or less noble intentions.
My thanks for your excellent guidance. Ah! And yonder I spy the object of my pursuit.
What message and what charge would that be?
That is why I have come here to charge you, Gale, with its destruction. It is Mystra's belief that only you can.
It sounds like the most insidious of evils was actually Gale all along.
Fine, fine, I'll turn a deaf ear to the clarion calls with which my scorned stomach beseeches me. Graver matters are at hand.
He is not. But it seems that Mystra is.
No indeed. But I think she trusts me to.
I was bid to spare neither time nor my own self to find you. She sent me, Gale. You know of whom I speak.
If the goddess herself is aware, I wouldn't say no to some divine intervention.
My'Nahastra Mystra'Ryl. E'Deelion Thras'Anas'Tthra.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Elinster speaks this spell and as he does so and makes hand gestures, a magical effect emanates from him and envelops Gale.
EditorData.VFXTags: VFX magic effect on hand of Elminster and around Gale

Text.Value: Plenty to digest, after all. A good deal to stew over, if you will. Words ladled with import should be savoured so as to better absorb their meaning, wouldn't you agree?
Yes, Gale. Where is your decorum?
Hogwash. Idle beliefs and false hopes.
If this is truly Mystra's will, I will do my best to see it done.
On my honour, it shall be done.
Not in so many words, no.
Gale alone? How so?
By circumstance, but not by purpose, I swear. I never intended you any harm.
Do you mean to say you never bothered to disclose how dangerous you are?
And a great kindness that would be! See, Gale? Even in these barren parts, the art of hospitality begets inspired new works if one only keeps up the practice.
That which renders him so dangerous is an orb of Netherese origin that is buried within his chest. And that, Gale, is how we arrive at the heart of my directive.
I, er... ahem. That is to say...
Interesting. This could be help or hindrance - we shall have to see.
Interesting. This could be help or hindrance - we shall have to see.
You know where you went wrong, Gale. We needn't dwell on that here and now. But even so, you're to be given a chance of redemption.
I don't understand. How so on my behalf?
I'm here on behalf of Mystra. The message and the charge I bring you are hers.
Nor would I expect you to. It is too bleak a task to demand of anyone.
It must be a great honour to be so entrusted by your god.
I am not his keeper, and I do not accept your charge.
Farewell, Elminster. I'm glad she chose you.
I could debate you on that.
They choose the instruments of their will with great precision. Sometimes the single drops we think we are do not realise what waves we are building up to be.
I'm surprised she sent you in the first place after Gale's... debacle.
Mystra has granted me the power to stop the clock, as it were, on the orb's rush to overpower you. Instead, you will be able to unleash its lethal combustion at will.
I'm glad it's not just me.
Nigh a tenday I've gone without honest fare worthy of the name - drank naught but what the sky entitled my thirst.
Ah, finally they stir. True adventurers get up with the lark, I always say, but if there are larks to be found in these lands, they must fancy themselves akin to nightingales.

EditorData.CinematicNodeContext: Elminster is at camp when the players and Gale wake up.

Text.Value: Elminster.
Young man, has your sojourn away from Waterdeep washed away your decorum as well as your patience?
You wouldn't happen to know of a cure, would you? Some all-powerful, parasite-withering spell, perhaps?
Farewell, my friend.
Mystra's delicate feet are ill-suited for the hardships of the road.

Synopsis:
Gale is a Companion.
This dialogue can trigger as COM (if the players approach Elminster with Gale as a companion), as a regular dialogue (if the players approach Elminster while Companion Gale is in the camp) or a CFM (if the player skips Elminster altogether).
It can trigger in either Creche or SCL.
